sen.j: 修学院離宮（しゅがくいんりきゅう）は京都市左京区の比叡山麓にある宮内庁所管の離宮である。
sen.e: Shugakuin Imperial Villa is a detached Palace within the Imperial Household Agency's jurisdiction, and it is located at the foot of Hiei-zan Mountain in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Shugakuin Imperial Villa is a detached Palace within the Imperial Household Agency's jurisdiction, and it is located at the foot of Mount Hiei-zan in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.
Shugakuin Imperial Villa is a detached Palace within the Imperial Household Agency's jurisdiction, and it is located at the foot of Mt. Hiei in Sakyo Ward, Kyoto City.

sen.j: 17世紀中頃（1653年（承応2年） - 1655年（承応4年））に後水尾天皇の指示で造営された。
sen.e: It was built in the middle of 17th century (1653 - 1655) under the order of the Emperor Gomizunoo.
It was built in the middle of 17th century (1653 - 1655) under the orders of the Emperor Gomizunoo.
It was built in the middle of 17th century (1653 - 1655) under the orders of the Emperor Gomizunoo.

sen.j: 桂離宮・仙洞御所とならび、王朝文化の美学の到達点を示すものとなっている。
sen.e: It is equaled by Katsura Imperial Villa, Sento Imperial Palace, it shows an achievement of the dynasty culture's aesthetics.
It is equaled by Katsura Imperial Villa, Sento Imperial Palace and shows the achievement of dynasty culture and aesthetics.
It is equaled by Katsura Imperial Villa, Sento Imperial Palace and shows the achievement of court culture and aesthetics.

sen.j: 概要
sen.e: Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 修学院離宮は上御茶屋（かみのおちゃや）、中御茶屋（なかの－）、下御茶屋（しもの－）と呼び習わす3か所の庭園からなり、面積は54万平方メートルに及ぶ。
sen.e: Shugakuin Imperial Villa consists of three gardens called Kami no O-chaya, Naka no O-chaya, Shimo no O-chaya, and it is 540.000 square meters in area.
Shugakuin Imperial Villa consists of three gardens called Kami no O-chaya, Naka no O-chaya, Shimo no O-chaya, and it is 540.000 square meters in area.
Shugakuin Imperial Villa consists of three gardens called Kami no O-chaya, Naka no O-chaya, Shimo no O-chaya, and it is 540.000 square meters in area.

sen.j: 各御茶屋の間には田畑が広がり、細い松並木道が各御茶屋を結んでいる。
sen.e: There are fields spread amongst each garden, and they are connected with narrow roads lined with pine trees.
There are fields spread amongst each garden, and they are connected with narrow roads lined with pine trees.
There are fields spread amongst each garden, and they are connected with narrow roads lined with pine trees.

sen.j: 上御茶屋と下御茶屋は、後水尾上皇（第108代天皇）の指示により、1655年（明暦元年）から1659年（万治2年）にかけて江戸幕府が造営した離宮である。
sen.e: Kami no O-chaya, Shimo no O-chaya are Imperial Villas which were built between 1655 to 1659 by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) under the order of the retired Emperor Gomizunoo. (the hundred and eighth Emperor)

Kami no O-chaya, Shimo no O-chaya are Imperial Villas which were built between 1655 to 1659 by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) under orders of the retired Emperor Gomizunoo. (the hundred and eighth Emperor)

Kami no O-chaya, Shimo no O-chaya are Imperial Villas which were built between 1655 to 1659 by the Edo bakufu (Japanese feudal government headed by a shogun) under orders of the Retired Emperor Gomizunoo (the hundred and eighth Emperor).

sen.j: 後水尾上皇は女中に変装して輿に乗り、造営中の離宮を自ら訪れて造営の指図をしたというが、真偽のほどは定かでない。
sen.e: It is said that the retired Emperor Gomizunoo visited Imperial Villa when it was under construction, disguised himself as a maid and got onto a palanquin, to direct it's construction, but this is not confirmed whether if this is true story or not.

It is said that the retired Emperor Gomizunoo visited the Imperial Villa when it was under construction, disguising himself as a maid and got onto a palanquin, to direct it's construction, but this is not confirmed as to whether it is a true story or not.

It is said that the Retired Emperor Gomizunoo visited the Imperial Villa when it was under construction, disguising himself as a maid and got onto a palanquin, to direct it's construction, but this is not confirmed as to whether it is a true story or not.

sen.j: 上・下御茶屋は1884年（明治17年）、宮内省の所管となった。
sen.e: Kami no O-chaya, Shimo no O-chaya became the Imperial Household Agency's jurisdiction in 1884.
Kami no O-chaya, Shimo no O-chaya came under the Imperial Household Agency's jurisdiction in 1884.
Kami no O-chaya, Shimo no O-chaya came under the Imperial Household Agency's jurisdiction in 1884.

sen.j: 一方、中御茶屋は、同じ頃後水尾上皇の皇女の御所として造営されたもので、1885年（明治18年）に修学院離宮に編入された。
sen.e: On the other hand, Naka no O-chaya was built as an Imperial Palace for the retired Emperor Gomizunoo's Imperial princess around same time, and it was incorporated into Shugakuin Imperial Villa in 1885.
However, hand, Naka no O-chaya was built as an Imperial Palace for the retired Emperor Gomizunoo's Imperial princess around same time, and it was incorporated into Shugakuin Imperial Villa in 1885.
However, Naka no O-chaya was built as an Imperial Palace for the Retired Emperor Gomizunoo's Imperial princess around same time, and it was incorporated into Shugakuin Imperial Villa in 1885.

sen.j: 修学院離宮は、第二次大戦後は、京都御所、桂離宮などと同様、「皇室用財産」（所有者は国）と位置づけられて、宮内庁が管理している。
sen.e: After World War Ⅱ, Shugakuin Imperial Villa, like Kyoto Imperial Palace and Katsura Imperial Villa, was placed as an Imperial Assets (owned by nation), and it is under the Imperial Household Agency's control.

After World War Ⅱ, the Shugakuin Imperial Villa, like the Kyoto Imperial Palace, and the Katsura Imperial Villa, were all designated as Imperial Asset (owned by nation), and are under the Imperial Household Agency's control.

After World War, the Shugakuin Imperial Villa, like the Kyoto Imperial Palace, and the Katsura Imperial Villa, were all designated as Imperial Asset (owned by nation), and are under the Imperial Household Agency's control.

sen.j: 見学には、事前に宮内庁京都事務所に、郵送・直接申請あるいはインターネットを通じて申し込んで許可を得る必要がある。
sen.e: To visit, it is necessary to obtain a permission from the Imperial Household Agency's kyoto office by mail or direct application or through internet application beforehand.
To visit, it is necessary to obtain permission from the Imperial Household Agency's kyoto office by mail or direct application or through an internet application beforehand.
To visit, it is necessary to obtain permission from the Imperial Household Agency's Kyoto office by mail or direct application or through an internet application beforehand.

sen.j: また18歳未満の者の見学はできない。
sen.e: Also, visitors under eighteen years old are not able to visit the Villa.
Also, visitors under eighteen years of age, are not allowed to visit the Villa.
Also, visitors under eighteen years of age, are not allowed to visit the Villa.

sen.e: Facilities
Facilities

sen.j: 下御茶屋
sen.e: Shimo no O-chaya
Shimo no O-chaya
Shimo no O-chaya

sen.j: 池泉観賞式庭園で、門・塀以外の建物と柿葺（こけらぶき）の屋根を乗せた簡素な建物である。
sen.e: It is an ornamental pond style garden and is a simple building which has a building except gate and fence and is roofed with shingles.
This is an ornamental pond style garden and it has a simple building roofed with shingles, there is no gate or fence.
This is an ornamental pond style garden and it has a simple building roofed with shingles, there is no gate or fence.

sen.j: 水墨の襖絵は後水尾上皇時代のものではなく、江戸後期の絵師・岸駒（がんく）および岡本豊彦の筆になる。
sen.e: The black ink paintings on fusuma are not from the retired Emperor Gomizunoo era, but they are painted by painters from late Edo period, Ganku and Toyohiko OKAMOTO.
The black ink paintings on the fusuma are not from the retired Emperor Gomizunoo era, but they were painted by painters from the late Edo period, Ganku and Toyohiko OKAMOTO.
The black ink paintings on the fusuma are not from the Retired Emperor Gomizunoo era, but they were painted by painters from the late Edo period, Ganku and Toyohiko OKAMOTO.

sen.j: 寿月観前庭の飛び石や、庭に立つ袖石灯篭も有名である。
sen.e: The Steppingstone in the front garden of Jugetsukan and Sodeishi lantern which stands in the garden are also famous.
The Steppingstones in the front garden of Jugetsukan and the Sodeishi lantern which stands in the garden are also famous.
The Steppingstones in the front garden of Jugetsukan and the Sodeishi lantern which stands in the garden are also famous.

sen.j: 中御茶屋
sen.e: Naka no O-chaya
Naka no O-chaya
Naka no O-chaya

sen.j: 後水尾上皇の第8皇女・光子内親王のために1668年（寛文8年）造営された朱宮（あけのみや）御所が前身である。
sen.e: It was originally built as Akenomiya Palace, completed in 1668, and this was built for the retired Emperor Gomizunoo's 8th Princess, Imperial Princess Teruko (Mitsuko).
It was originally built as Akenomiya Palace, completed in 1668, and this was built for the retired Emperor Gomizunoo's 8th Princess, Imperial Princess Teruko (Mitsuko).
It was originally built as Akenomiya Palace, completed in 1668, and this was built for the Retired Emperor Gomizunoo's eighth Princess, Imperial Princess Teruko (Mitsuko).

sen.j: 朱宮御所は上皇の死後、林丘寺（りんきゅうじ）という寺に改められていた。
sen.e: After the death of the retired Emperor Gomizunoo, Akenomiya Palace was changed to a temple called Rinkyu-ji Temple.
After the death of the retired Emperor Gomizunoo, Akenomiya Palace was changed into a temple called Rinkyu-ji Temple.
After the death of the Retired Emperor Gomizunoo, Akenomiya Palace was changed into a temple called Rinkyu-ji Temple.

sen.j: 1885年（明治18年）、楽只軒（らくしけん）と客殿を含む、林丘寺境内の約半分が宮内省に返還され、修学院離宮の一部となった。
sen.e: In 1885, about a half of the precincts of the Rinkyu-ji temple which included Rakushiken and a guest hall were returned to the Department of the Imperial Household and it became a part of the Shugakuin Imperial Villa.

In 1885, about a half of the precincts of the Rinkyu-ji temple which included Rakushiken and a guest hall were returned to the Department of the Imperial Household and became a part of the Shugakuin Imperial Villa.

In 1885, about a half of the precincts of the Rinkyu-ji temple which included Rakushiken and a guest hall were returned to the Department of the Imperial Household and became a part of the Shugakuin Imperial Villa.

sen.j: なお、林丘寺は門跡尼寺として今も存続している。
sen.e: Furthermore,The Rinkyu-ji Temple is still retained as a convent whose chief nun is an Imperial Princess.
Furthermore,The Rinkyu-ji Temple is still retained as a convent whose chief nun is an Imperial Princess.
Furthermore, the Rinkyu-ji Temple is still retained as a convent whose chief nun is an Imperial Princess.

sen.j: 楽只軒は前述の朱宮御所の一部で、1668年（寛文8年）頃の造営である。
sen.e: Rakushiken is a part of the Akenomiya Palace which is described earlier and was built around 1668.
Rakushiken is a part of the Akenomiya Palace which is described earlier and was built around 1668.
Rakushiken is a part of the Akenomiya Palace which is described earlier and was built around 1668.

sen.j: 書院造の客殿は、1677年（延宝5年）造営された東福門院（後水尾天皇女御、徳川2代将軍秀忠娘）の女院御所の奥対面所を移築したものである。
sen.e: The guest hall of the Shoin zukuri (a traditional Japanese style of residential architecture that includes a tokonoma) was reconstruction of 奥対面所 of Nyoin Palace (the palace for the court ladies who received In title or equivalent) in Tofukumon in. (Emperor Gomizunoo's court lady, Tokugawa second Shogun, Hidetada's daughter)
sen.cmt: 奥対面所→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: The guest hall of the Shoin zukuri (a traditional Japanese style of residential architecture that includes a tokonoma) was a reconstruction of 奥対面所 of Nyoin Palace (the palace for court ladies who received In title or equivalent) in Tofukumon in. (Emperor Gomizunoo's court lady, Tokugawa second Shogun, Hidetada's daughter)

The guest hall of the Shoin zukuri (a traditional Japanese style of residential architecture that includes a tokonoma) was a reconstruction of 奥対面所 of Nyoin Palace (the palace for court ladies who received In title or equivalent) in Tofukumon in (Emperor Gomizunoo's court lady, Tokugawa second Shogun, Hidetada's daughter) which was constructed in 1677.
sen.cmt: which was constructed in 1677.補足翻訳者コメント同様

sen.j: 客殿一ノ間の霞棚は、桂離宮の桂棚、醍醐寺三宝院の醍醐棚とともに「天下三棚」の一として知られる。
sen.e: The Kasumi dana of the Ichinoma of the guest hall is known as one of the Tenka Sandama (Unrivaled three shelves) together with Katsura Dana of the Katsura Imperial Villa,Daigo Dana of the Daigo-ji Temple Sanboin.

The Kasumi dana of the Ichinoma in the guest hall is known as one of the Tenka Sandama (Unrivaled three shelves) together with Katsura Dana of the Katsura Imperial Villa,Daigo Dana of the Daigo-ji Temple Sanboin.

The Kasumi dana of the Ichinoma in the guest hall is known as one of the Tenka Sandama (Unrivaled three shelves) together with Katsura Dana of the Katsura Imperial Villa, Daigo Dana of the Daigo-ji Temple Sanboin.

sen.j: 上御茶屋
sen.e: Kami no O-chaya
Kami no O-chaya
Kami no O-chaya

sen.j: 巨大な人工池の浴龍池（よくりゅうち）と大刈込を中心とした壮大な庭園である。
sen.e: It is a magnificent garden which has a massive artificial Yokuryu-chi Pond and 大刈込 as main feature.
This is a magnificent garden which has a massive artificial Yokuryu-chi Pond and 大刈込 as the main feature.

This is a magnificent garden which has a massive artificial Yokuryu-chi Pond and Okarikomi (many trees are individually planted with the top parts of the trees cut into one shape as a whole to create special look of the background or main part of the garden) as the main feature.
sen.cmt: 大刈込→Okarikomi「大刈込」は、「庭園の主景もしくは背景として、多数の樹木を密植し、その樹冠を全体として大きく一つに刈り込んだ仕立」です。その意味で訳し直しました。

sen.j: 御幸門から石段を上った離宮内の最高所に隣雲亭が建つ。
sen.e: Rin un-tei Pavilion stands at the highest place in the Imperial Villa after climbing up the stone steps from Miyuki-mon Gate.
Rin un-tei Pavilion stands at the highest place in the Imperial Villa after climbing up the stone steps from Miyuki-mon Gate.
Rin un-tei Pavilion stands at the highest place in the Imperial Villa after climbing up the stone steps from Miyuki-mon Gate.

sen.j: ここまで登ると、急に展望が開け、眼下に浴龍池、遠方に借景の山々を望む壮大な風景が広がる。
sen.e: Once climbing up here, the view opens up suddenly, there is Yokuryu-chi Pond below and a magnificent view of surrounding mountains spreads in the distance.
Once climbing up here, the view suddenly opens up, there is Yokuryu-chi Pond below and a magnificent view of the surrounding mountains spreads in the distance.
Once climbing up here, the view suddenly opens up, there is Yokuryu-chi Pond below and a magnificent view of the surrounding mountains spreads in the distance.

sen.j: 隣雲亭は1824年（文政7年）の再建で、展望を目的とした、装飾のほとんどない簡素な建物で、床（とこ）・棚も設けていない。
sen.e: Rin un-tei Pavilion was rebuilt in 1824 for the purpose of observation, and is a simple building with hardly any decorations and there are also no alcove or shelves.
The Rin un-tei Pavilion was rebuilt in 1824 for the purpose of observation, and is a simple building with hardly any decorations and there is also no alcove or shelving.
The Rin un-tei Pavilion was rebuilt in 1824 for the purpose of observation, and is a simple building with hardly any decorations and there is also no alcove or shelving.

sen.j: 内部は6畳の一ノ間、3畳の二ノ間と6畳間3室からなる。
sen.e: Inside consists 6 mats room Ichi no ma, 3 mats room Ni no ma and three 6 mats rooms.
The inside consists a 6 mat room Ichi no ma, 3 mat room Ni no ma and three 6 mat rooms.
The inside consists three rooms; a 6 mat room Ichi no ma, 3 mat room Ni no ma and a 6 mat room.

sen.j: 一ノ間北東の板張りの縁は「洗詩台」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: The (external) corridor with a boarded floor at north east of the Ichi no ma is called 'Senshidai'.
The (external) corridor with a boarded floor running north east of the Ichi no ma is called 'Senshidai'.
The (external) corridor with a boarded floor running north east of the Ichi no ma is called 'Senshidai.'

sen.j: 軒下の三和土（たたき）には赤と黒の小石が埋め込まれ「一二三石（ひふみいし）」と呼ばれている浴龍池には中島、万松塢（ばんしょうう）、三保ヶ島という3つの島があり、土橋、楓橋、中国風の千歳橋の3つの橋が架かる。
sen.e: A hard-packed concrete floor under the eaves is packed with red and black pebbles, and in the Yokuryu-chi Pond which is called 'Hifumi ishi' has three Islands called Nakano-shima Island, Banshou, Mihoga-shima Island and three bridges called Do-bashi Bridge, Kaede-bashi Bridge, and a Chinese style Chitose-bashi Bridge are built on them.

A hard-packed concrete floor under the eaves is packed with red and black pebbles, and in the Yokuryu-chi Pond which is called 'Hifumi ishi' there are three Islands called; Nakano-shima Island, Banshou, Mihoga-shima Island and three bridges called; Do-bashi Bridge, Kaede-bashi Bridge, and a Chinese style Chitose-bashi Bridge are built across connecting them.

A hard-packed concrete floor under the eaves is packed with red and black pebbles, and in the Yokuryu-chi Pond which is called 'Hifumi ishi' (one-two-three stone) there are three Islands called; Nakano-shima Island, Banshou, Mihoga-shima Island and three bridges called; Do-bashi Bridge, Kaede-bashi Bridge, and a Chinese style Chitose-bashi Bridge are built across connecting them.

sen.j: 中島には窮邃亭（きゅうすいてい）が建つ。
sen.e: Kyusui-tei Pavilion stands on Nakano-shima
Kyusui-tei Pavilion stands on Nakano-shima
Kyusui-tei Pavilion stands on Nakano-shima

sen.j: 窮邃亭は修学院離宮において創建当時のまま残る唯一の建築で、三間四方、柿葺（こけらぶき）、宝形造（ほうぎょうづくり）。
sen.e: In Shugakuin Imperial Villa, Kyusui-tei Pavilion is the only building which remained since when it was built, it is 三間四方, roofed with shingles and Hogyo-zukuri.
sen.cmt: 三間四方→読み方、定訳不明
sen.e: In the Shugakuin Imperial Villa, the Kyusui-tei Pavilion is the only building which has remained since it was built, it is 三間四方, roofed with shingles and Hogyo-zukuri.
In the Shugakuin Imperial Villa, the Kyusui-tei Pavilion is the only building which has remained since it was built, it is Sangen shiho (5.5 m square), roofed with shingles and Hogyo-zukuri.
sen.cmt: 三間四方→Sangen shiho (5.5 m square)

sen.j: 内部は18畳1室である。
sen.e: Inside is a one room with eighteen mats.
Inside is one room of eighteen mats.
Inside is one room of eighteen mats.

sen.j: 京都市バス 修学院離宮道から徒歩15分
sen.e: The Kyoto City Bus fifteen minutes' walk from Shugakuin rikyu michi
The Kyoto City Bus fifteen minutes' walk from Shugakuin rikyu michi

sen.j: 叡山電鉄叡山電鉄叡山本線修学院駅から徒歩20分
sen.e: Eizan Electric Railway Eizan Line twenty minutes' walk from Shugakuin Station
